_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is a re-submission of the RMP submitted May 8, 2000 by Conectiv Operating Service Company [COSC].  The EPA facility ID# is 1000 0016 9293.

The construction of the Delaware City Power Plant [The Power Plant], formerly Delmarva Delaware City Power Plant, was the result of an agreement between Tidewater Oil Company and Delmarva Power & Light in the mid 1950's.  The majority of the steam and electricity produced was dedicated for use in the Tidewater Delaware City Refinery operations.  The first boiler was placed into service in 1955.  Under terms of the agreement, Delmarva Power financed the construction of the Power Plant and Tidewater contracted Delmarva Power to operate the facility with an option to purchace the facilities at the end of the thirty-year agreement period.  After several extensions of the agreement, Star Enterprise exerc ised their option to purchase the Power Plant facilities in 1992.  Delmarva Power & Light merged w ith Atlantic Electric Company in 1998 to form a holding company known as, Conectiv.  Star Enterprise formed a limited partnership in 1998 with Shell, Texaco and Saudi Aramco under the name Motiva Enterprises, LLC [Motiva].  Motiva contracted Conectiv Operating Services Company [COSC], which was a subsidiary of Conectiv, to operate and maintain the power plant and facilities associated with the Repowering Project, which was scheduled for initial operation in year 2000.  As of January 2003 Conectiv operates the Delawaree City Power Plant through its subsidiary Delaware Operating Services Company [DOSC].  Under the terms of the an Operating and Maintenance Agreement, DOSC assists complying with the regulatory requirements applicable to the power plant operations, including the Delaware Accidental Release Prevention Regulation.  The RMPs currently on file designate Motiva as the owner of the Refinery and the Power Plant.  Premcor Refinery Group Inc. purchased the Refinery and Power Plant from Motiva, effective May 1, 2004.

(a) Acciden

tal Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Power Plant boilers are designed to fire a mixture of fuels including petroleum coke, refinery fuel / natural gas, and No. 6 fuel oil.  The petroleum coke and the refinery fuel gas are by-products from the Delaware City refinery operations.  Refinery Fuel Gas is a mixture of refinery gases and natural gas transported through an overhead pipeline to the power plant facilities.  The Refinery Fuel Gas is comprised mostly of methane and is not stored on site.  In September 1989, the Refinery Fuel Gas process became regulated on Delaware's former risk management of Extremely Hazard Substance Regulations because the Potential Release Quantity from the Refinery Fuel Gas process at the power plant exceeds the regulatory release rate threshold [sufficient quantity, SQ] for methane.  The power plant registered the RFG process with Delaware Department of Natural Resources & Environmental Control [DNREC] in December 1993.  On June 21, 1999 COSC submitted a Risk Management Plan to DNREC for a covered process, Refinery Fuel Gas, under a Program 1 status.

The Repowering Project encompassed the manufacture of synthetic gas from petroleum coke and included the construction of petroleum coke gasifiers, combustion turbines, heat recovery steam generators, an air separation plant and other equipment, as well as modifications to the power plant.  As a result of the construction of the Repowering Project, COSC had identified additional covered processes as defined by the Delaware Accidental Release Prevention Regulaton [DARPR] associated with the Gasificaton Process [manufacture of synthetic gas-syngas].  Consequently, in April / May 2000 COSC revised the Risk Management Plan [RMP] that had been submitted to include the original covered process [Refinery Fuel Gas] and additional covered processes.  The covered processes are defined as stated in section [b].  On June 21, 2004 DOSC re-submitted the Refinery Fuel Gas RMP as covere

d process No. 1 [CP 1].

The Delaware City Refinery and Power Plant are members of the Delaware City Community Action and Emergency Response [DC-CAER] group.  The DC-CAER group members support and work closely with local response organizations, including New Castle County LEPC, to prevent accidental releases and mitigate the consequences of an accidental release by preparing coordinating response plans in the event of an accidental release.  DOSC has a Safety Program that is central to its operations and maintenance activities.  The Facility Manager has overall responsibility for maintaining an effective safey program.  In compliance with DARPR, DOSC is committed to maintaining effective Risk Management Programs for the identified covered processes.

(b) Stationary Sources [Covered Processes] and Regulated Substances

DOSC has identified the following covered processes and has concluded that three are subject to Section 6 of the DAPRP and one is subject to Section 5 of DAPRP.  Section 5 of DAPRP is the incorporation of 40CFR Part 68 Chemical Accidental Release Prevention Provision requirements into DAPRP.  Section 6 is Delaware's extension of 40CFR Part 68 that had previously been the Delaware "Regulation for the Management of Extremely Hazardous Substances".

Covered process No. 1 [CP1] is the Refinery Fuel Gas process with regulated substance methane [flammable].  CP1 is subject to Section 6 of DAPRP, requiring a submission of RMP to DNREC.

Covered process No. 2 [CP2] is the Liquid Hydrogen Storage & Supply System with regulated substance hydrogen [flammable].  CP2 is subject to Section 6 of DAPRP, requiring a submission of RMP to DNREC.

Covered process No. 3 [CP3] is the Natural Gas Supply System with regulated substance methane [flammable].  CP3 is subject to Section 6 of DAPRP, requiring a submission of RMP to DNREC.

Covered process No. 4 [CP4] is the Synthetic Gas Manufacturing Process with regulated substance syngas, a mixture of gases with hydrogen the id

entified regulated substance [flammable].  The hydrogen concentration in the syngas is great enough that the entire amount of synthesis gas is considered hydrogen for the purposes of determining the threshold quantity for RMP.  The quantity of H2S in the process is greater than the OSHA PSM standard threshold, 1500 pounds.  Subsequently, the syngas process is subject to the OSHA PSM Standard and, consequently, CP4 is classified as a RMP Program 3 process. Therefore, CP4 is subject to Section 5 of DAPRP, requiring a submission of RMP to Federal EPA.

This RMP submittal is for CP4, Synthetic Gas Manufacturing Process.

CP4 - Syngas Manufacture

The Syngas Manufacturing Process [CP4] contains the regulated flammable substance, hydrogen.  The weight percent of hydrogen in the syngas varies from 1.02 percent to 2.9 percent within the process.  In accordance with DARPR Section 1.115 (b) (1) and 40 CFR 68.115 (b) (2), if the regulated substance is present in concentrations of one percent or greater by weight, then the entire weight of the mixture shall be treated as a regulated substance [unless it can be demonstrated that the mixture does not have a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Rating of 4].  Syngas is associated with a NFP rating of 4.  The total amount of syngas stored within the process has been calcuated at 23,220 pounds, which is greater than the 10,000 pound threshold quantity. Subsequently, CP4 is considered subject to DARPR Section 5, requiring the associated RMP submittal to the Federal EPA.

The total amount of hydrogen sulfide stored within the CP4 process has been calculated at 2,067 pounds, which is less than the 10,000 - pound threshold quantity.  Therefore, a worst-case release scenario is not required for this regulated substance with respect to Section 5 of DARPR.  The amount of hydrogen sulfide in certain pipelines within the process would exceed the sufficient quantity [SQ] specified in Section 6 of DARPR.  In recognition of this fact, an

alternate case has been defined and analyzed for the offsite consequence of an accidental release described below.

( c ) Worst & Alternate - Case Release Scenarios and Offsite Consequence Analysis

The worst-case release scenario for CP4 ocnsiders the release of the capacity of the Acid Gas Absorber [AGA], 7212  pounds of syngas, as the regulated flammable substance.  The AGA is common to both syngas manufacturing trains and is the largest capacity vessel in the process.  The distance to the endpoing is based on the Risk Management Program Guideline for Offsite Consequence Analysis [flammable mixtures, section 5-2 and Appendix C].  Since the syngas is a gas mixture that includes components with significantly different heats of combustion, the method described in Appendix C with Equation C-2 is utilized to calculate the distance to the endpoint.  In accordance with this method, non-flammable components of the syngas are not included.  The distance to the endpoint is calculated at about 0.1 miles [528 feet].  The worst-case release scenario does not impact residential populated areas and environmental receptors.  The worst-case release scenario impacts one public receptor, the Metachem LLC industrial facility immediately north of the site.  The worst-case release scenario is depicted on Figure CP4-3, which is included in a graphic file CP4-3.GIF.

The alternative-case release scenario for the flammble substance hydrogen considers a release of syngas through a hole that is  1 sqare inche in area, from a vessel or pipe.  The distance to the endpoint as defined by RMP*Comp [Version 1.07] is 0.1 miles [528 feet].  The alternate-case release scenario does not impact residential populated areas and environmental receptors.  The alternative-case scenario impats one public receptor, the Metachem LLC industrial facility immediately north of the the site.  The alternative-case release scenario is depicted on Figure CP4-4, which is included in a graphic file CP4-4.GIF.

The li

sted toxic substance, hydrogen sulfide [H2S], is a major component of the acid gases returned to  the sulfur recovery unit [SRU] in the refinery.  In recognition of the general duty responsibility [DARPR Section 3], an alternative-case release scenario has been identitied and analyzed for an accidental release from this pipeline.  This alternative release considers a rupture of the overhead pipe carrying the recovered acid gas to the SRU and H2S is released for 60 minutes before the unit can be shutdown.  The distance to the endpoint as defined by RMP*Comp [Version 1.07] is 0.6 miles [3168 feet].  The alternative-case release scenario does not impact residential populated areas and environmental receptors.  The alternative-case release scenario impacts four public receptors immediately north and northease of the site - Metachem LLC, Keneka, Oxychem, and Chlormone sites.  The alternative-case release scenario is depicted on Figure CP4-5, which is included in a graphic file CP4-5.GIF.

Administrative controls [including the facility operating, maintenance and training procedures and good engineeringn practices] limit the probability of an accidental release.  Safety features are part of the design of the process, including pressure relief systems, flare systems automatic computerized process control, and incorporation of redundant equipment.  The adequacy of administrative controls has previously been tested with 30-35 operating plants worldwide.

(d) General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The design of all systems at the facility is by professional engineers providing good engineering practice in accordance with industry and government codes and standards. This includes conducting PHA activities during the design stage of the process development.  CP4 is operated and maintained per OSHA PSM Standards.

CP4 has been in operation since year 2000. A PHA for the syngas manufacturing process was conducted in 19 sessions for a

period slightly greater than 1 month culminating in report dated February 2004.  The HAZOP included consideration of "human factor" concerning the operation of CP4.  Evaluation of the considered items for action remains a constant activity at the facility.

(e) Five Year Accident History

During the period since year 2000, the facility experienced three incidents associated with accidental releases of syngas. Each incidient was investigated and an Incident Investigation Report was completed.  Each of the incidents did not result in significant offsite consequences.

(f) Emergency Response Program

The Delaware City Power Plant and Refinery are members of the Delaware City Community Action and Emergency Response [DC-CAER] group.  The DC-CAER group members support and work closely with local response organizations, including the New Castle County LEPC, to prevent accidental releases and mitigate the consequences of an accidental release by preparing coordinated response plans in the event of an accidental release.

(1) DOSC has a written emergency response plan [ERP]. 
(2) The ERP details action to be taken in the response to fires that would be the likely result of an accidental release of the regulated flammable substance and actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of the toxic substance hydrogen sulfide, H2S.
(3) The ERP includes procedures for informing the public and local agencies for responding to accidental releases, and notifying impacted public receptors.  Specifically, the ERP includes procedures to inform local fire department and hospital staff to respond to minor accidents that require public assistance; and DC-CAER and New Castle County LEPC to respond to major accidents.
(4) The ERP includes information ablout emergency health care, specifically for ashpyxiation and treatment of burns [either from direct fire or crygenic liquid exposures].
(5) The date of the most recent review of the ERP is March 01, 2005.

(g) Planned Changes - Safety Improvement / Management of Change Procedures

DOSC practices safety management on a proactive basis.  Safety management and improvement are integrated are integrated on a continuous basis with the operation, maintenance and training activities of the facility.  Scheduled safety meetings are held.  The facility enforces a Management of Change procedure.  Scheduled outages for maintenance of equipment are planned.
